meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>criminal</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical> will always be <kanji>sad</kanji>. No one chooses a life of crime if they're happy. And even if they seem like they're doing fine on the outside, deep down they're really sad.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sad</kanji> feelings fill the criminal's body with <reading>he</reading>at (ひ). This heat spreads and radiates out. If you walk next to them on the street, you'll feel the sad heat floating by you.

meaning_mnemonic: If there is a <radical>drum</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> it's time to <kanji>rejoice</kanji>! And because of your mouth drum your rejoicing will be loud and booming!
reading_mnemonic: You loudly <kanji>rejoice</kanji> for a while when suddenly someone runs over and shoves a <reading>key</reading> (き) in your mouth, locking it shut. You can't rejoice anymore! You need that key to unlock your mouth!

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>original</radical> radical and the <kanji>original</kanji> kanji are the same!

This kanji can also mean <kanji>field</kanji>, probably because that's what everything originally looked like before humans: just a bunch of fields.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> Japanese hero was <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji."

meaning_mnemonic: If you take a <radical>thread</radical> and plant a <radical>rice paddy</radical> on it, the rice paddy is going to be extremely <kanji>thin</kanji>, but also <kanji>detailed</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>thin</kanji> rice paddy is for your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). You gave your cyborg a very thin human stomach, so it can only digest one thin line of rice at a time.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> can be used for <radical>comfort</radical>, but also for <kanji>medicine</kanji>. Sure, it’s a comfort to smell flowers because they smell nice, but one can also use them as medicine to heal people.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to transport all the <kanji>medicine</kanji> on land is with a <reading>yak</reading> (やく). Yaks are big, strong, and very capable of transporting flower medicine like these.

meaning_mnemonic: You're all by your lonesome <radical>self</radical> and have to check each <radical>rice paddy</radical> you own, all <radical>twenty</radical> of them! Luckily, you have a very astute <kanji>nose</kanji>, allowing you to quickly assess the state of your twenty rice paddies all by yourself.
reading_mnemonic: As you're about to finish checking your paddies, your <kanji>nose</kanji> picks up an additional smell: It's <reading>Hannah</reading>, bringing you a bunch of <reading>花</reading> (はな)!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>shellfish</radical> has a <radical>knife</radical> in its <kanji>side</kanji>. It's fine though, don't worry, it's just a reminder that he won the great shellfish war back when they were trying to choose the new leader.
reading_mnemonic: Because of this knife in his <kanji>side</kanji>, he can't pronounce certain words correctly. The most obvious one is when he says <reading>川</reading> (かわ), but it comes out of the side of his mouth as がわ.

meaning_mnemonic: When you swing your <radical>axe</radical>, the <radical>ground</radical> ends up covered in <radical>fins</radical>, because you're a <kanji>soldier</kanji>. Only a skilled axe soldier could make such precise cuts as to de-fin a bunch of fish like that.
reading_mnemonic: Uh-oh, it looks like this axe <kanji>soldier</kanji> was so excited about chopping the fins off his fish that he didn't think about how he was going to cook them. The only thing nearby to light on fire is a bale of <reading>hay</reading> (へい). Well, it's not the best thing, but at least it will get these fish cooked.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> will empty his <radical>mouth</radical> of all its <radical>dirt</radical> in the great <kanji>hall</kanji>. They all get together in some kind of <kanji>public chamber</kanji> and dish all the dirt (literal and figurative) that they've got.
reading_mnemonic: While the Vikings gather to spill the dirt in their <kanji>hall</kanji>, they also stuff their faces with <reading>dou</reading>ghnuts (どう). Ah yes, Vikings love to eat doughnuts when they talk trash.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>dirt</radical>, there's a <radical>gun</radical>. Its <radical>mouth</radical> points toward a <radical>plate</radical>. What's on the plate? Why, it's <kanji>salt</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: When you see the <kanji>salt</kanji>, you think to yourself, "<reading>She owe</reading>s (しお) me big time, so I'm going to go ahead and snatch her salt!" Who is she, you ask? She's the lady who owns the salt. And the gun in the dirt, of course.

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>yurt</radical> you use a <radical>towel</radical> as a <kanji>seat</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Something about using a towel for a <kanji>seat</kanji> is very <reading>sexy</reading> (せき) to you. Probably because you associate it with sexy people using towel seats on the beach.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>shellfish</radical> that can't live through <radical>winter</radical> is a <kanji>failure</kanji>. Any proper shellfish would survive through the winter, so this is quite an embarrassing <kanji>defeat</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to avoid <kanji>failure</kanji> is to say a little <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい) to distract you from the cold. In fact, this can work in any situation where you're afraid of defeat. Say a haiku aloud, it will calm your nerves and warm you from the inside.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fruit</radical> radical and the <kanji>fruit</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Bodacious!
reading_mnemonic: They sell <kanji>fruit</kanji> at the store, and you need to drive your <reading>ca</reading>r (か) to get there. A car is the fastest way to fruit.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> you aim your <radical>gun</radical> at from your <radical>window</radical> is an <kanji>ume</kanji>, aka a <kanji>Japanese plum</kanji>. Why? Because shooting the ume out of Japanese plum trees is, in your opinion, the best way to harvest plums.
reading_mnemonic: You've probably heard of <kanji>ume</kanji> before, depending on your exposure to Japan, but an <reading>ume</reading> (うめ) is a <kanji>Japanese plum</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>nothing</radical> radical and the <kanji>nothing</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Woah!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Nothing</kanji> can <reading>moo</reading> (む) quite like a cow can moo. Cows are the best at going moo. That’s a fact.

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>thread</radical> for <radical>good luck</radical> by <kanji>bind</kanji>ing two fingers together. You <kanji>tie</kanji> them nice and tight.
reading_mnemonic: After you <kanji>bind</kanji> your fingers, the good luck starts pouring in. Literally. Suddenly <reading>ketsu</reading>p (けつ) starts pouring down from the heavens.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> is so <radical>big</radical> that it's the <kanji>cause</kanji> of all your problems.
reading_mnemonic: Your big mouth is the <kanji>cause</kanji> behind all your friends and family moving to an <reading>inn</reading> (いん). They move to the inn so they don't have to live with you and hear you talk anymore.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>viking</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>towel</radical> is a totally <kanji>normal</kanji> thing. It's <kanji>ordinary</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: It's <kanji>normal</kanji> for a viking to have a mouth towel, but your sloppy farmhand friend <reading>Joe</reading>(じょう) has a mouth towel too. That's a habit that's only <kanji>normal</kanji> for vikings, so why does he have one?

meaning_mnemonic: If you can <radical>say</radical> what <radical>sound</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> makes, you must be very <kanji>discerning</kanji>. Few people are able to discern what sound a drunkard makes, but you — you can say, because you're a very <kanji>discriminating</kanji> listener.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Discerning</kanji> individuals like you are considered <reading>chic</reading> (しき). What's more chic than your <kanji>discriminating</kanji> way of listening?

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>criminal</radical> has done an <kanji>injustice</kanji> on the world or other people. Being a criminal is a <kanji>negative</kanji> thing, and even if it was just a <kanji>mistake</kanji>, it was still a crime.
reading_mnemonic: When you commit an <kanji>injustice</kanji>, you'll know because <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) fills your body. Maybe you've never done any kind of big thing, but when you make a <kanji>mistake</kanji> your face fills with heat and you turn red!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dry</radical> radical and the <kanji>dry</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>dry</kanji> Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). He hates being wet, all of the Mongols do, so your job is to dry his entire body. And his clothes, and his horse. In fact, when it rains, you have to ride next to him keeping him dry by holding an umbrella above his head.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is <radical>correct</radical>, <kanji>absolutely</kanji>. The mighty sun is never wrong. It is absolutely correct, always.
reading_mnemonic: Then, a <reading>ze</reading>ppelin (ぜ) flies in front of the sun, blocking it out. <kanji>Absolutely</kanji>, the sun cannot ignore this transgression. Therefore, the sun corrects the zeppelin’s evil ways by frying it with sunshine and bringing it to the ground.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, and you want to <radical>walk</radical> over it, so you have to <kanji>ford</kanji> it. You don’t walk across a tsunami, you <kanji>wade</kanji> across it.
reading_mnemonic: Your ability to <kanji>ford</kanji> this tsunami impresses everyone who witnesses it, especially the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). Now that you've taught him a tsunami can be forded, he's going to start sending his troops through them instead of waiting for them to pass.

meaning_mnemonic: Under this <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>bear</radical> who works for the <kanji>government</kanji>. If you saw a bear out in the wild you might be afraid and try to run, but if you see a bear inside a building under a roof, don't be scared! It's just a government bear.
reading_mnemonic: The first <kanji>government</kanji> that allowed bears was set up by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). He was all about conquering people and then using them as efficiently as possible. He discovered that bears are incredibly useful in government buildings as government workers.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're on the <radical>roof</radical> of the <radical>festival</radical> you'll have to <kanji>guess</kanji> what's actually going on below you. You can kind of see that there are rides and maybe food? It smells like food. But you have to guess on the specifics because you're above it and not in it.
reading_mnemonic: To get a better <kanji>guess</kanji>, you ask <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) for help. She's that little girl you know from some earlier mnemonics, and she happens to be up on the roof with you. Picture her as you ask, "What's your guess, Satsuki?"

meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>canopy</radical> your <radical>clan</radical> digs in the <radical>ground</radical>, trying to get to the <kanji>bottom</kanji>. They want to build a nice home your entire clan can live in, but they need to get to the bottom before they'll start building.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly someone down in the hole shouts that they've reached the <kanji>bottom</kanji>, but it's full of water and they're all <reading>soak</reading>ed (そこ)!

meaning_mnemonic: Put on <radical>cleat</radical>s so you can plant a kiss on your sweetheart's <radical>forehead</radical> in the <radical>heart</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> — that's <kanji>love</kanji>. You'll be braving the harsh winter elements for love, so you put on your cleats to get a better grip on the snow. Sure, you could just wait for better weather to go see them, but then it wouldn't be true love, would it?
reading_mnemonic: Walking through the winter snow with your cleats on, you've gotta keep your <reading>eye</reading> (あい) on the prize. It's a really hard journey, but you keep your eye on the prize, which is your <kanji>love</kanji> and the time you'll get to spend with them.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>net</radical> is for <radical>someone</radical> who works in a <kanji>government office</kanji>. You'll also take someone from a <kanji>political office</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Government office</kanji> and <kanji>political office</kanji> people put on the best <reading>show</reading>s (しょ). That's why you want to capture someone from there with your net.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>poem</radical> about <radical>winter</radical> that you <radical>say</radical> to <kanji>warn</kanji> people against going outside. It's cold and dangerous in winter! You <kanji>admonish</kanji> anyone and everyone you see going out there with your scary winter poem.
reading_mnemonic: To make sure people listen to your <kanji>warn</kanji>ing, you threaten to take away their <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい). People will do anything for cake, so when you bring it up, they actually take your attempts to warn them about winter seriously.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Again</radical> and again, your <radical>heart</radical> comes back to the same person. Is this <kanji>romance</kanji>? Are you in <kanji>love</kanji>?
reading_mnemonic: But, remember that your <kanji>romance</kanji> isn’t a <reading>ren</reading>tal (れん). You really wanna reserve it for the right person!

meaning_mnemonic:
<radical>Viking</radical> <radical>see</radical>, Viking <kanji>memorize</kanji>. That’s how Vikings learn things. They see something, and then they memorize it. Quite simple, really.

It can also mean <kanji>awake</kanji>. Just remember that Vikings can't see if they aren't awake. There won't be anything to memorize if their eyes are still closed, after all!
reading_mnemonic: Every morning, a <reading>cock</reading> (かく) crows and rouses the Vikings. Seeing this, one of the Vikings <kanji>memorize</kanji>s the cock crow so that he can mimic it and play pranks on his fellow Vikings.

meaning_mnemonic: What do you <radical>say</radical> to a <radical>guard</radical>? Your <kanji>theory</kanji> about how the thing he's guarding isn't even real. Yeah, you have this whole thing figured out. You have for a while. At this point, it's only fair that you tell your theory to the guard who's wasting his time.
reading_mnemonic: The guard listens to your <kanji>theory</kanji> but then he says his OWN! He thinks there are two <reading>sets</reading> (せつ) of guarded items, and he's only guarding one. According to his theory, either one could be real! His theory is more plausible, don't you think?

meaning_mnemonic: You hide <radical>poop</radical> in a <radical>cape</radical> as part of the <kanji>illusion</kanji> in your magic show. Your acts are kind of gross and this one involves creating the illusion of disappearing poop by hiding it within the folds of your cape.
reading_mnemonic: Somehow the poop cape <kanji>illusion</kanji> goes over really well. The crowd is giving you a standing ovation and right in the center is <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん). He marches up to you, wipes a tear from his eye, and says, "Your illusion cape is wonderful. I must have it!"

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>sheep</radical> are <kanji>detailed</kanji> creatures. I mean, I never thought sheep were very detailed, but that’s what they say.
reading_mnemonic: The reason these sheep are so <kanji>detailed</kanji> is that they are trying to impress the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). If they're fancy enough, perhaps the Shougun won’t kill them for their meat and make their wool into clothing.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tiger</radical> kills a <radical>pig</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> in this new <kanji>drama</kanji> about the animal kingdom! The tiger and pig used to be friends when they were younger, but now they're bitter enemies and the tiger just stabbed the pig right in the chest with a knife.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>drama</kanji> is being put on by <reading>Gecki</reading> (げき), your childhood pet gecko. Gecki is playing all the parts, because as true drama fans know, one-gecko-shows are the highest form of art.
